text: English grammar lesson 6 topic verb
tenses our focus will be on the present
perfect and the present perfect
progressive
this is part three and we'll now
practice forming the negative and
forming questions in the present perfect
how do we form the negative in the
present perfect the helping verb have or
has is followed by not and then the past
participle example there has not been a
change of plans or there hasn't been a
change of plans
the contractions then are the following
have not becomes haven't has not becomes
hasn't and remember you can use these
contractions or short forms in spoken
English or in informal writing
exercise 1 complete the statements with
negative verbs in the present perfect
number 1 read the statement to yourself
and then I'll tell you the answer answer
my husband and I don't go to many formal
events he hasn't worn a tuxedo in years
number 2
answer I live in the suburbs of Boston I
haven't gone downtown for almost a month
I don't have much reason to travel far
from home number three
answer my children enjoy visiting this
local farm but they haven't been there
since early October let's talk about
forming questions we'll begin with
yes/no questions here's the structure
use the helping verb however has plus
the subject plus the past participle
let's look at two examples have you
taught children has she studied other
languages watch the answers we can use
short answers to these yes/no questions
they are yes I have or no I haven't yes
she has or no she hasn't so it's not
necessary to give a full answer with the
past participle
note we often use the adverb ever in
questions about general past experience
for example have you ever taught
children if you choose to use ever place
it between the subject in your main verb
now let's talk about information
questions here's the structure begin
with a question word such as where who
how then choose a helping verb have or
has followed by the subject followed by
the past participle the structure is
used in the first two examples below
where have you traveled who have you
traveled with the structure changes only
when the question word who is about the
subject for example who has traveled
more you or him
exercise to form questions based on the
answers provided number one let's work
together the answer is I've only visited
the Philippines once your clues are in
black visited and once so our main verb
in the question will be visit and once
tells you that we need to ask a question
about how many times so let's begin with
our question word or question phrase
which is how many times helping verb
have subject you main verb visit it so
our full question is how many times have
you visited the Philippines answer I've
only visited the Philippines once that's
the sad truth but hopefully I'll make
another visit in the future number two
look first at the answer yes I have I
only drove a little I rode behind the
driver most of the time you have two
clues yes and road think what kind of
question do you need to ask and what
will be the form of your main verb I'll
give you a moment to form the question
the question is have you ridden a
snowmobile you could also ask have you
ever ridden a snowmobile number three
again look first at the answer yes I
have I think you can say I was seriously
injured when I burned my hands on the
kitchen oven I was 1 or 2 at the time
again I gave you some clues yes
tells you that this will be a yes or no
question your main verb is injured but
look closely was injured
that's the passive voice take a moment
and try to form the question on your own
the question is have you ever been
seriously injured and yes that is me in
the photograph with bandaged hands as a
little girl this is a true story I did
burn my hands on the kitchen oven
I think this is a good time to pause and
review let's see what you remember from
earlier parts of this lesson why do we
use the present perfect there were three
reasons we looked at the first reason is
to state that something began in the
past and continues to the present the
second reason is to express an
unfinished period of time an action
likely happened repeatedly and may
happen again a third reason is to talk
about past actions at unspecified times
to talk about general past experience
now let me present one more reason this
will be our fourth reason for using the
present perfect we also use the present
perfect to report events that happened
in the recent past so we can talk about
the distant past meaning a long time ago
in the recent past a short time ago here
are two examples the first there's been
a change of plan so the change took
place recently perhaps just yesterday
second example congratulations you've
just won a million dollars
so this news is very recent the event is
recent the effect or effects of that
recent event are still seen or still
felt in the present for example when I
say there's been a change of plan
perhaps the change took place yesterday
but that means today things are very
different they're different from what we
expected they would be and if you've
just won a million dollars
perhaps you won that money yesterday and
you still have that money today
let's see how well you've understood
everything so far we'll try an exercise
exercise three read the statement and
then answer the question number one have
you seen any good films lately your
answer can be very short and very
general yes I have or no I haven't but
if you choose to give me specific
information with specific times and
dates then you need to use the simple
past for example yes yesterday I saw a
very interesting film number two how
many English language videos have you
watched in the past three days your
answer should use the present perfect
for example I've watched three videos
number three have any of your personal
or professional plans changed over the
past few months and I'll let you be as
general or specific as you'd like
we're not quite done yet please go on to
the last part of this lesson be sure to
watch part 4 we're going to practice
using time expressions and I'll finally
explain when we use the present perfect
progressive I'll see you there
